>

Gather around the “FIRE!, FIRE!, FIRE!”, for I have a story passed down for centuries (not actually but you know what I mean)
column482: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column487:
>

“FIRE!, FIRE!, FIRE!” by Salvador Dali
column494: class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" align=""center""><tr><td class=""v"" align=""center"" valign=""middle"" height=""42"" style=""height:42px
column495: ><a href=""https://twitter.com/_Zoharks"" target=""_blank"" rel=""noopener noreferrer nofollow"" style=""font-size:19px
column497: > FOLLOW ME ON TWITTER
column499:
>

Salvador Dali, one of the most iconic artists of the 20th century, was known for his surreal and avant-garde paintings. However, what many people may not know is the story of his wife, Gala, who abused Dali'
column500: s fame and talent by making him sign fakes and empty sheets of paper, which she then sold as original artworks. This essay explores the history of Dali and Gala&#39
column501: s relationship and how her actions impacted his legacy.
column504: s wife but also his muse, model, and manager. She was responsible for organizing his exhibitions, managing his finances, and promoting his work. However, she also had a darker side, which became apparent as their relationship progressed.
column507: s popularity skyrocketed, and his paintings became highly sought after by collectors and art dealers. Gala saw an opportunity to capitalize on her husband&#39
column508: s fame and began making him sign blank canvases and empty sheets of paper. She would then fill these with her own paintings or those of other artists and sell them as Dali originals. This practice became so common that it became known as the &quot
column511: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column516:
>

“Giraffe on Fire” by Salvador Dali
column519: s motivation for this fraudulent activity is unclear. Some have speculated that it was purely for financial gain, while others believe that she wanted to undermine Dali&#39
column520: s legacy and reputation. Whatever her motive, her actions had a lasting impact on Dali&#39
column521: s reputation and the art world as a whole.
column524: s death in 1989, many of the artworks attributed to him were found to be forgeries. Experts discovered that many of these paintings were signed by Dali but were not actually his work. Instead, they were created by other artists or even by Gala herself. This discovery led to a wave of lawsuits and legal battles as collectors and dealers sought to recover their losses.
column531: class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" align=""center""><tr><td class=""v"" align=""center"" valign=""middle"" height=""52"" style=""height:52px
column534: > READ MORE: A Call to My Fellow Artist
column537: s fraud also had a significant impact on Dali&#39
column538: s legacy. His reputation was tarnished by the revelation that many of his most famous works were actually fakes. This discovery called into question the authenticity of his entire body of work, leaving many wondering how much of it was actually created by him and how much was the work of others.
column540:
>

In addition to the legal and reputational fallout, the Gala-Salvador Dali fraud also had a significant emotional impact on Dali. According to some accounts, Dali was devastated when he learned that his wife had been selling fakes under his name. He reportedly went into a deep depression and withdrew from the public eye for a time. The betrayal by his wife, who he had trusted with his career and legacy, was a blow that he never fully recovered from.
column541: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column547:
>

The story of the Gala-Salvador Dali'
column548: s fraud is a cautionary tale of how even the most talented and successful artists can fall victim to exploitation and manipulation. The abuse of Dali&#39
column549: s fame by his wife not only had a lasting impact on his reputation and legacy but also caused emotional pain and suffering for the artist himself. As we continue to admire the works of Salvador Dali, it is important to remember the complex and sometimes dark history behind his art.

column481:
>

ROME IS WHERE THE HEART IS, THE START OF A MODERN-DAY DIGITAL RENAISSANCE
column482: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column487:
>

“Martyr in the Heavenly Realm” by Saeed
column489:
>

I recently caught myself diving into the depths of art, visual culture, and the understanding of how the renaissance is constantly being reflected in our current art world now (I suggest these depths not be entered), I have also been reading a book called “Nothing if Not Critical” by Robert Hughes. I think the critic he was and the criticism he shared was so valuable to the art world, including myself, as he has opened my mind to scale when it came to understanding the arts and how I go about unpacking my personal theories I take on dates.
column491:
>

Robert Hughes was a firm believer that the culture of politics, economics, and mass media ruins art he also felt strongly that the late modern collections from Canberra to Minneapolis to Venice were all purchased from the same menu. I always wonder if this correlates to how Alberti felt when he stood tall against the art patrons about the uses of gold and promoting majesty.
column493:
>

The Italian Renaissance was attached to the prestige of Roman and Greek cultures where words, paintings, and sculptures were weighed so heavily because of the intent behind wanting to represent a time of shared pearls of wisdom. The digital art world is promoting the same prestige due to the force of outside societies but having the willingness to share practices that have been around since the first computer was made while their intent remains mindful.
column500: class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" align=""center""><tr><td class=""v"" align=""center"" valign=""middle"" height=""42"" style=""height:42px
column503: > READ ABOUT ARTIST MARIANO SANGALLI
column505:
>

ARTISTS HAVE WHAT THE AVERAGE PERSON COULD TEND TO NOT HAVE AND THAT IS FUNCTION. (Something like an exponent)
column507:
>

What is your function as an artist?
column509:
>

You should not confuse this with “what utility does your work possess” or “finding ways to describe what your art means”. This is about what degree an artist stands for and what he or she believes and how they go about using their tools to provide. I sent out a tweet that was on how our digital visual language is officially representing how we are and where we are in the world. This was a standing point on the term “Bourgeois Art” created by Peter Burger which reflects on a broad conceptual framework, which views artistic developments as being driven ultimately by social and economic change.

>

In the time I spend reading essays, books, and other things involving the art world I may find myself diving head-first into, the one thing that I always understood buying art is like a religious belief, it involves an act of faith. The value placed on pure genius is something unmeasurable.

column495: class=""dd"">
column497: >“You stand in front of a picture like that and what is money”
column506:
>

The value of art lies in less quantifiable reals ran by beauty, quality, and rarity, which becomes manipulatable and becomes treated as a commodity, the spiritual, intellectual, and aesthetics are often mixed with the social and aspirational.
column507: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column514:
>

This is what has occurred in our present century, a wise man once said “Today’s art world is fantasy-driven” that wise man was Phillip Hook. Could that possibly be that there is more passion than rationality?
column516:
>

The keyword “Cultural Cringe” what does it mean? and what does it pertain to?
column518:
>

Cultural cringe is the assumption that whatever you do in the field of film, writing, painting, architecture, sculpture, dance or theater is of unknown value until it is judged by people outside your own society.

column9: > Rogues’ Gallery: The Rise (and Occasional Fall) of Art Dealers, the Hidden Players in the History of Art, by Philip Hook &#160

column439: > Art History 101:
column448: > Rogues’ Gallery: The Rise (and Occasional Fall) of Art Dealers, the Hidden Players in the History of Art, by Philip Hook
column449: class=""dd""><table class=""mob-block"" role=""none"" width=""100%"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" align=""center""><tr><td aling=""center"" valign=""middle""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" align=""right"" class=""socialShare mob-stack""><tr><td align=""left"" valign=""middle""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" align=""left"" style=""width:140px
column478: data-open-tracking=""true""> {{OPEN_TRACKING_PIXEL}}
column479: ><table role=""none"" width=""100%"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" align=""center""><tr><td class=""dd"" align=""left"" style=""padding:0px 15px
column481:
>

A fascinating exploration of the often-overlooked role of art dealers in shaping the art world as we know it today. Hook takes readers on a journey through the history of art dealing, from its humble beginnings as a trade dominated by shady characters and rogues, to its current status as a highly sophisticated and regulated industry.
column483:
>

One of the main themes of the book is the tension between the art world’s commercial and artistic aspects. While artists may create works for the sake of art, art dealers exist to sell these works for a profit. Hook notes that this tension has existed since the earliest days of art dealing when dealers would often use unscrupulous tactics to convince collectors to buy their wares. However, as the industry has evolved, so too has the relationship between dealers and artists. Today, many dealers have close relationships with the artists they represent, and work to support their careers and promote their work.
column490: class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" align=""center""><tr><td class=""v"" align=""center"" valign=""middle"" height=""52"" style=""height:52px
column491: ><a href=""https://lu.ma/zoharksgallery0808"" target=""_blank"" rel=""noopener noreferrer nofollow"" style=""font-size:21px
column493: > Register for Zoharks Gallery “08+08” Exhibition
column494: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column499:
>

“Mirrored sisters looking for something forgotten between the papers” by Leon Vilhena
column501:
>

Another key theme of the book is the idea that art dealers have played a crucial role in shaping the canon of art history. As Hook notes, the art world has long been dominated by a small group of powerful collectors and dealers who have the ability to influence which artists and artworks are considered important. This can have significant implications for artists and their legacies. For example, Hook discusses the case of the British artist John Martin, who was hugely popular in the early 19th century but fell out of favor in the years following his death. It was not until the 20th century that his work began to be reappraised and recognized once again as important. This example illustrates how the actions of dealers and collectors can have a significant impact on the way in which artists are perceived by the wider world.
column503:
>

Throughout the book, Hook profiles a number of art dealers, both past and present, who have made significant contributions to the art world. These profiles offer a fascinating glimpse into the lives of these often enigmatic and mysterious figures. For example, Hook writes about the legendary art dealer Joseph Duveen, who made his fortune selling Old Master paintings to American collectors in the early 20th century. Duveen was known for his impeccable taste and his ability to charm even the most difficult clients. However, he was also a controversial figure, and many accused him of artificially inflating the prices of the works he sold.
column504: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column510:
>

One of the strengths of Rogues’ Gallery is Hook’s ability to convey the sheer complexity of the art world. He does an excellent job of explaining the many different factors that can influence the value and significance of a work of art, from its provenance and condition to the opinions of experts and collectors. At the same time, he never loses sight of the human element and is careful to highlight the personal relationships and rivalries that can drive the art world.
column512:
>

While Rogues’ Gallery is a highly engaging and entertaining book, it is not without its flaws. For one thing, some readers may find the book’s tone to be a bit too lighthearted at times. Hook has a tendency to inject humor into even the most serious topics, which may not be to everyone’s taste. Additionally, some readers may be disappointed by the book’s narrow focus on the world of high-end art dealing. While Hook does touch on the role of dealers in other areas of the art world, such as the contemporary art market, he primarily focuses on the world of Old Masters and Impressionist paintings.
column514:
>

Despite these minor criticisms, Rogues’ Gallery is a highly recommended read for anyone with an interest in the art world. Whether you are a seasoned collector or a casual admirer of art, Hook’s book offers a fascinating glimpse into
column516:
>

column490: >Zoharks Gallery is an NFT gallery, striving to showcase great artists who are shaping the future. You are being invited to our latest exhibition, titled &quot
column492: . countless hours were spent researching and selecting artworks from a diverse range of artists, all of whom offer unique perspectives on the theme of the future of art. This topic was chosen because
column493: >@_zoharks
column496: > believes that the way we see and interpret the world is essential to understanding ourselves and the world around us. Art has the power to change our perception and alter the way we see things.
column501: >Through this exhibition, we hope to create an experience that allows visitors to explore their perceptions in new ways. The exhibition features artworks that challenge traditional perceptions of reality. The collection is rounded out by the stunning portraiture which invites the viewer to question the very nature of perception itself. The
column502: >@zoharksgallery
column506: >goal in hosting this exhibition is to offer visitors an opportunity to question their assumptions and explore the hidden depths of perception.
column511: ><a class=""link"" href=""https://t.co/lSGxexxbpn"" target=""_blank"" rel=""noopener noreferrer nofollow"">Zoharks Gallery &quot
column518: >This exhibition is particularly relevant today as we live in an age where technology has drastically altered the way we perceive the world around us. As you explore the collection, we encourage you to ask yourself questions such as: How do these artworks change the way I see the world? How do artists use color, shape, and form to manipulate perception? What is the relationship between perception and reality? We hope that this exhibition will provoke thought, imagination, emotion, and creativity, and inspire visitors to think differently about the way they see the world. looking forward to seeing you at the exhibition and encouraging you to engage with the artworks and explore the unseen.

column497: ><table role=""none"" width=""100%"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" align=""center""><tr><td class=""dd"" align=""left"" style=""padding:0px 15px
column499:
>

I want to say thank you to Mariano Sangalli for taking the time to help accomplish the bridging of my questions with personal answers.
column501:
>

The aim of this Essay and Interview with Mariano Sangalli is to share my philosophies and beliefs on an artist I have collected and have visually fallen in love with. When I was setting up the Zoharks Gallery for the “08+08” exhibition I could not help but question the senses I kept feeling when looking back on what I had collected from the artist so I wanted to pick Mariano’s brain.
column504: font-family:TwitterChirp, -apple-system, system-ui, Segoe UI, Roboto, Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif
column505: >Exploration of similarities and differences.
column508: font-family:TwitterChirp, -apple-system, system-ui, Segoe UI, Roboto, Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif
column509: >They say photography is the sister of cinema, I insert in that Mariano Sangalli would be the brother of creating cinema-like feelings but with a canvas creating scenes as if it was stop-motion. This makes me question the complexity of what makes a still image and what is considered a moving picture when something is still but flows like a stream of water moving quietly and undetected.
column512: font-family:TwitterChirp, -apple-system, system-ui, Segoe UI, Roboto, Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif
column513: >Sangalli’s work seems to seek different cognitive capacities and senses
column516:
>

mortality, Emotion, Truth.
column517: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column524:
>

This is where my mind takes me and signals to me when looking at the pieces by Sangalli. As a jazz lover and art lover I made an argument that we can no longer compare art to jazz. With new innovations, we are forced to move to a different type of beat, I believe the beat is moving at the speed of electronic music or a Hans Zimmer soundtrack
column526:
>

I find myself contradicting myself after hours of listening to Hans Zimmer while looking over some of the works of Sangalli, with each track and some repeated tracks. I found myself with the thesis that Sangalli has the same philosophical landscape and tempo as performing arts.
column528:
>

When I looked at works like “Corporeity: by Mariano Sangalli and Sonia Perez, I could not help but look at the art piece as a contemporary performance that is conceived as an NFT.
column529: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column534:
>

Corporeity by Mariano Sangalli and Sonia Perez
column538:
>

“Inside” was a piece that made me reflect on my personal life and asked myself about the things I once doubted about myself, relationships, and hardships that were faced in life. It was almost as if the more I went through artworks, the more I felt like I was in a therapy session between my conscious thoughts, my reflections, and the artworks which created a connection that was built through every single piece.
column539: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column548:
>

My connection became so strong that I decided to interview Mariano Sangalli, for who I am grateful and thankful for spending the time answering each question to make this reading possible.
column551: font-family:TwitterChirp, -apple-system, system-ui, Segoe UI, Roboto, Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif
column552: >Is there anything you want to show to people when you create a piece?
column555: font-family:TwitterChirp, -apple-system, system-ui, Segoe UI, Roboto, Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif
column556: >no, or at least not something specific, I only try to generate an evocation, a sensation of space, and an empty narrative, so that the viewer can complete it. you could say that it is a container that the viewer fills.
column559: font-family:TwitterChirp, -apple-system, system-ui, Segoe UI, Roboto, Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif
column560: >Whenever I look at your works of art I feel the story
column561: > being told, do you feel there’s intent in telling the story or is it for the viewer to see the story told?
column564: font-family:TwitterChirp, -apple-system, system-ui, Segoe UI, Roboto, Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif
column565: >I think I answered part of this answer before, but to go deeper, I could say that I leave structures of a story that is not told so that the viewer can finish building it with his own story. I try to balance evocation and narrative, which sometimes come out and sometimes do not.
column566: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column571:
>

small paintings 3 by Mariano Sangalli
column573: ><h2><span style=""font-family:TwitterChirp, -apple-system, system-ui, Segoe UI, Roboto, Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif
column574: >What are the little things you enjoy in life?
column577: font-family:TwitterChirp, -apple-system, system-ui, Segoe UI, Roboto, Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif
column578: >The little things in life? a complex question. what is small and what is big? hehe, I guess I could sum it up in the detail. I enjoy being able to appreciate the details, the little things. a leaf that moves in the wind, a little ornament in some new place I see, that kind of thing
column580: ><h2><span style=""font-family:TwitterChirp, -apple-system, system-ui, Segoe UI, Roboto, Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif
column581: >How easy is it for an artist of caliber to bridge and reflect between your past, present, and what you see in the future?
column585: font-family:TwitterChirp, -apple-system, system-ui, Segoe UI, Roboto, Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif
column586: ><b>about the past and the present I could say that it is not easy, but it is an interesting exercise, every few periods (once or twice a year) I display all my works in the workshop, to see what they tell me about what I have already done and what I am doing now, and every time I do it I find new things. I am in a constant dialectic exercise between the past and the present of what I do. and in relation to the future, it is totally uncertain for me because I don&#39
column587: t know how my work can be modified in the future, what new techniques or crafts I will learn. To give you an example, getting into digital art and NFT has changed considerably my way of working.
column590: font-family:TwitterChirp, -apple-system, system-ui, Segoe UI, Roboto, Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif
column591: >Who is the one artist who spoke to you through
column595: font-family:TwitterChirp, -apple-system, system-ui, Segoe UI, Roboto, Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif
column596: ><b>With this question you mean who are my visual references? sorry if I don&#39
column597: t understand it, english is not my native language and maybe I miss some subtleties of the language. In case you mean my references, I could name some that come to my mind at this moment. Louise Bourgeois , Michaël Borremans, Lucian Freud, Bruno Walpoth, Gideon kiefer, Bill Viola, Pina Bausch

column500: >What’s the value of something? How do you actually view or value anything? Christie&#39
column501: s contemporary art sales in 2021 saw NFT sales accounting for 8% of the total sales, amounting to nearly $150 million from the sale of over 100 NFTs.
column503:
>

Following up with that In that same year Sotheby'
column504: s NFT sales reached almost $100 million. Surprisingly, 78% of NFT bidders were first-time customers of the New York-based auction house, and more than 50% of them were under 40 years of age.
column506:
>

Masses see the cost of NFTs such as what could be exchanged for them, and how much could be sold for. Missing the value that is in the communities where art pieces are created.
column508:
>

Understanding the Aesthetic Value or the commodity of something based on social is very challenging to translate, consider the social engagement amongst memes such as Notable Pepe’s or PFP NFTs such as crypto punks.
column514: ><table width=""100%"" cellpadding=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" border=""0"" role=""none""><tr><td width=""100%"" style=""padding: 0 0 14px 0
column517: ><table width=""100%"" cellpadding=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" border=""0"" role=""none""><tr><td width=""36"" style=""width:36px
column535:
>

🤯You could call @Vince_Van_Dough's first round of Notable Pepe card drops a success.

The cheapest card is at 0.95 ETH, and the Pepe's Chair card (100 supply) is already at 6.65 (with a 5 WETH offer).

The Pepe Checks have surged 50% to 0.0333 as folks buy up those raffle tix. https://t.co/b5TJhExqIK
column563:
>

What do both of these represent?
column565:
>

They represent new models, models that showcase the inseparability of culture you know whose been around for a certain amount of time in the NFT space by simply looking at a profile picture or you can tell what blockchain someone is a part of by looking at their Twitter name or Twitter bio. Ever seen a user on the app with aname.eth?
column567:
>

Due to this representation, I believe people have forgotten the data and find it hard to help find the solution to bringing art to the digital world. Being a lover of museums I understand that all the art in most museums are on the internet and anyone could more than likely go secure a photo of any painting they want and have a copy and do as they please with it.
column569:
>

There are critics who would argue NFTs are not art but they carry the same characteristics of “Academic Art” as flat digital works have pictorial space that is an illusion of 3D - dimensional space. Works with code in for 3D movements and visualization, artwork within the present time with what is shaping their reality and it gets expressed as a visual message to whatever forced them to respond.
column570: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column577:
>

There are echoing forms and valuable vibrant tones that are still weighted very heavily into an NFT, but in reality, most don’t actually care about that. They actually in fact care about the data of what is being provided on what to trade and buy next. There are different opinions but I’m a collector who collects art to showcase the world of our future.
column579:
>

The value of the artist is what is being Valued here by the communities backing them up which is cutting out the greed and capitalizing on creators who fund for companies who then stop providing.
column581:
>

That’s the value and why NFTs have innovated art and should be respected and I advise education on the subject.

column500:
>

How do we truly trace innovation in the contemporary world?
column502:
>

Hold that question in your mind until the end, for centuries we have been living under the impression an art piece was good because it looks just like a photograph and was realistic.
column504:
>

Then more criticism entered the room and decided that things were too realistic but Salon de Paris still only accepted what was real to them. Innovation was not being traced there to see this new world of being able to create a vision through techniques that were based on studied principles and codes amongst the community of independent artists.

column514: >Georges Pierre Seurat was one of the French post-impressionist artists who had unintentionally carved another road for modern art &quot
column515: A Sunday afternoon on the island of La Grande Jatte&quot
column516: is what was considered the initial steps in the development of the new technique called Divisionism (pointillism) Georges studied with sculptor Justin Lequiene and attended the Ecole Des Beaux -Arts in 1878 and 1879 Most artist have a moment when they discover a book, paintings, sculptures or a life experience.
column519: font-family:TwitterChirp, -apple-system, system-ui, Segoe UI, Roboto, Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif
column520: >Just like the great painter Rene Magritte came about Giorgio de Chirico - &quot
column521: the song of love” painting. Georges came across the book &quot
column523: by Humbert de Superville Artists of this time understood their relationship with depicting the tones, and understand the power of controlling the aesthetic by showing relationships between lines, images, colors, and shapes.
column524: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column529:
>

Painting by George Seurat
column532: font-family:TwitterChirp, -apple-system, system-ui, Segoe UI, Roboto, Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif
column533: > Influencing color and tones to create a work of art that was created by the 3 primary colors Red, Yellow, and blue which was the impressionist color theory. What Seurat also did was create paintings that acted as mirrors telling the full story showing statuses and hidden criticism in his works the viewers know that his stories were true stories but in an abstract form
column536: font-family:TwitterChirp, -apple-system, system-ui, Segoe UI, Roboto, Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif
column537: >Georges Had a belief that modern art showed contemporary life the same way classical art did but used technologically innovative techniques like formality and symmetry which was heavy in the &quot
column539: a work of art that was seen as one of his most essential works of art. Balancing subjects, light, and symmetry all of his works took you through an emotion that you could almost feel as if you were watching from your own point of view while his later works were criticized by those who didn’t yet understand he was considered one of the forerunners of cubism.
column540: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column548: font-family:TwitterChirp, -apple-system, system-ui, Segoe UI, Roboto, Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif
column550: s paintings there is an orchestra in the room, and the volume at display comes from attributes that help viewers feel seen, heard, and felt like when the composer puts his hands in the air to signal we are about to start and all eyes are looking to the conductor creating anticipation.
column553: font-family:TwitterChirp, -apple-system, system-ui, Segoe UI, Roboto, Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif
column554: >That contributes to an emotion that then turns into a question. Rather it is trying to figure out what is being looked at or questioning your perspective on how you view the world, Seurat did an amazing job for the future course giving you insight into those questions being asked.

column481:
>

Being able to “see” art is a sense of communication between the visual works and the viewer. It gets to the point that whatever could have possibly been received through a composition.
column482: font-family:TwitterChirp, -apple-system, system-ui, Segoe UI, Roboto, Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif
column483: >The ability to connect with art is a form of communication between the artwork and its audience. It captures the essence of the composition, conveying its message to the viewer. During the 19th century, renowned artists carried smaller canvases to make their artwork more portable.
column485:
>

Nfts and artists are part of the current culture with the toolbox of code or artificial intelligence these things are what is currently shaping our future so our artists use those technologies to showcase modern life.
column487:
>

Painters of yesterday have no way of capitalizing off the work that was done just to be commercialized with no benefit.
column490: font-family:TwitterChirp, -apple-system, system-ui, Segoe UI, Roboto, Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif
column493: font-family:TwitterChirp, -apple-system, system-ui, Segoe UI, Roboto, Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif
column494: >However, with technological advancements, artists now have a myriad of options to showcase their work digitally and physically. Today, NFTs and artists are integral to our cultural landscape. With tools like code and artificial intelligence at their disposal, they are able to showcase modern life in new and exciting ways.
column495: font-family:TwitterChirp, -apple-system, system-ui, Segoe UI, Roboto, Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif
column500: font-family:TwitterChirp, -apple-system, system-ui, Segoe UI, Roboto, Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif
column501: >By utilizing these cutting-edge technologies, artists are shaping the future of the art world. Unfortunately, painters of the past had no way to benefit commercially from their work. However, the rise of NFTs and other digital innovations has created new avenues for artists to monetize their creations

>

My “NFT Radar” is a series that helps, artists and collectors, create a sense of connection through my curated selection of artists that is chosen to be spotlighted. Rather it is on an ongoing auction, collection, open editions, and more.
column490:
>

When I learned about Rene Magritte and the way he used “ordinary thoughts” to communicate through a visual medium using his thoughts and ideas.
column493: s lessons he learned during his time of being a painter helped me realize things differently as a collector.
column494: class=""dd""><table role=""none"" width=""100%"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" align=""center"" class=""d"" style=""border-radius:6px

column502: >“Art evokes the mystery without which the world would not exist”
column519:
>

In the present time where art has innovated to the digital scale it has grown to and where everyone can be an artist.
column521:
>

As a collector, it is important for "
column523: . Artists need to be Getting lost in the present/future world while using the past as reflection to answer those questions is going to be a good source tool for artists of today to excel on greater scales.
column525:
>

While building a connection with the artwork I try to sync with, I can’t help but have curiosity strike over and over again. What was the artist feeling how did they connect with what I am seeing as a viewer and how can I transcribe it?
column527:
>

This is why artists of today can be powerful because you can’t base NFTs on an art movement or compare one thing to another, you can only reflect on it using your current and past knowledge to understand so things are valued more as a purchaser because the masses are forced to relearn what they once knew.
column529:
>

As I was building out the follow spotlight for my “NFT Radar”, these were the lessons I held and kept close to my theories and thought processes while going through this curated collection

column483:
>

For many people art is a specific thing
column484: a painting, sculpture or photograph, a dance, a poem or a play. It is all of these things and more. They are mediums of artistic expression.
column487: s New Collegiate dictionary defines art as the &quot
column488: conscious use of skill and creative imagination, especially in the production of aesthetic objects&quot
column489: . Yet art is much more than a medium or words on a page. It is the expression of our experience.
column492: s Definition of art:
column494:
>

I see that translated into the NFT world. The same world that has grown, I have watched and taken notes on.
column496:
>

Art is uniquely human and tied directly into the culture, taking the ordinary and making it extraordinary.
column498:
>

The meaning of beauty and the human condition art is an expressive medium with codes in place that allows us to experience feelings rather it is joy, deep sorrow, or confusion.
column500:
>

It cracks the code on time connecting us to the past reflecting the present and anticipating the future
column502:
>

Form and content:
column504:
>

Form: The physical and visible characteristics inherent in works of art
column506:
>

Content: the meaning we derive from them
column508:
>

Formal distinctions include a work’s size, medium (painting, drawing, sculpture, or other kinds of work), and descriptions of compositional elements, such as the lines shapes, and colors involved.
column510:
>

Content distinctions include b. Content
column512:
>

There is less consensus here. Some distinguish "
column516: - - i.e., denotations. connotations, more or less
column517: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column535: Semiotics and post-structuralism go even farther, well beyond what can be introduced here. To simplify matters, content means &quot
column537: however that message may be organized. A traditional way of organizing content was simply to place it in basic categories of iconography (signs, symbols, conventions, etc.) called genres, listed here in what was once considered a descending order of importance:
column539:
>

History: important incidents like famous battles, political triumphs, social movements, etc
column541:
>

Megalography: the portrayal of historically important people or things in an absurdly glorifying manner, as if they weren’t really human or ordinary at all.
column543:
>

Mythology: stories of gods, goddesses, nymphs and heroes, usually (but not exclusively) Greek or Roman in origin
column545:
>

Religion: the portrayal of sacred narratives and legends from the worlds holy texts
column547:
>

Portraiture: likenesses of real people, usually (but not exclusively) of at at-least moderate social standing
column549:
>

Landscape: representations of places urban and rural whether real or imagined
column551:
>

Genre: not to be confused with “genres"
column552: ( the categories in general), the portrayal of scenes of everyday life, including people but not specifically for the purposes of portraiture
column554:
>

Still-life: objects, furniture, settings, utensils, flowers, food, etc without obvious stories or important people
column556:
>

Rhopography: trash, rubbish, waste

column563:
>

Issues of content include any visit to Al clubs that provide an understanding of what the art tells us. Sometimes an artwork'
column564: s content is vague or hidden and needs more information that is present in the work itself. Ultimately these two terms are roped together in the climb to understand what art has to offer to us
column566:
>

Aesthetics in the world of art is a philosophical argument about the beauty of the work of art in its current nature of it.
column568:
>

Art is embedded in the fabric of our lives, it is still the source of controversy and irony. Thriving in common experiences yet contradicting the ideas of ourselves.
column570:
>

Art is part of the culture it’s created in,, but can reflect many cultures at once where one might stand in the present time art has become even more complex when it comes to the use of imagery, mediums, and meanings. We need to access visual information unlocking it for our society from past cultures we have grown in living it in our current world or cultures unknown to most of the world
column572:
>

Art is a society of core thinkers that shape culture and humanity in a sense that scares those of great power using its soft power. The ability to be a free-floater thinker that can strike with a sense of charisma that shapes people to become a follower or a collector of one’s work is very impactful.
column574:
>

Art can not be weighed because of its ability to evolve on micro-economic scales and still not having a true measurement of its importance is truly influential.

column478:
>

We had a bloodbath this past week in the market, if you are new to the crypto space, welcome to the beginning. There were plenty of scares in the market and a lot of people spreading false information. When high cap coins like Bitcoin have a cool down period like this past week, you buy, find out your zones you would like to buy in and buy.
column479: class=""dd"" bgcolor=""transparent""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column483:
border=""0""/>

My focus through this past week was to buy as much Bitcoin, Cardano, Vechain and Litecoin as I could. Now what caused the crash? Well there’s the so called “whales” and over leveraged. The “whales” dumped into the market and brought the price down to get out leveraged and the retail investor out of the market. This example is why you don’t sell through panic
column484: stick to your thought process and stay strong. The over leveraged people are the guys who are buying into trades with borrowed money. A lot of these guys went long, so the whales shorted the market. The richest people in the crypto space just got in early and held their coins. They did not day trade or swing trade. The crypto space is the space where you can get rich if you’re doing the correct things.

column478: ><table role=""none"" width=""100%"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" align=""center""><tr><td class=""id-"" align=""center"" valign=""top"" style=""padding: 20px 15px 20px
column479: class=""dd"" bgcolor=""transparent""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column483:
border=""0""/>

Bitcoin is no longer a secret as the FED continues to be in agony. We have seen over the last few weeks to a month the number of bankers, companies, and Whales coming into the Bitcoin space trying to bait out the average retail investor trying to catch up. For ages, there has only been a few currencies that have kept their value. Considering the value of the dollar dropped 8.22% in 2020, the world has a new understanding of why something like Bitcoin is needed. If you own something rather it is a home, life savings, or that car you have always wanted
column484:
I'm pretty sure you would be in shambles if it were ever taken from you, right?

Well, that is Fiat for you. We hold it, we live on it and it can also help someone change their whole life. On the other hand, it has also caused a lot of panics. Knowing that it has depreciated, while inflation is creeping in causing prices to go up in living, food, and gas there has been fear created within the markets.

People wonder what can save us. Is it real estate, gold, or silver? The answer is Bitcoin. In my opinion, physical silver is a good add-on but Bitcoin is the main focus. In a sense, BTC is all 3 of those. It can be seen as real estate, bitcoin is property, you own it. It will never be taken from you unless someone hacks you but there are measures you can take to keep that from happening. Bitcoin has value like an asset. Assets are scarce and that is what allows that object or item to withhold more value than most. Most families hold onto gold or items made of gold, but with BTC and its limit of 21 million BTC, this creates a sense of an asset. Once the max is reached it will become harder to buy shares or own a piece of Bitcoin.

With gold, we all know or have a sense of the bank manipulation at play, when you are a part of the blockchain no matter how much money you have, no matter how much power you have, you are seen as everyone else which makes the blockchain and Bitcoin far more superior than any company or bank.

I mention silver because silver has so many applications, industrial applications, thermally conductive, and electronically conductive. Silver is a great wealth preserver, a great protector of what can be passed down. It will only grow from where it is now considering there are only trace amounts of silver used in industrial applications. Bitcoin is known for its applications and allowing people to start preserving and building wealth. As you can see with El-Salvador acquiring BTC as a tender, could save the whole monetary system unlike Fiat keeping those in charge on top of things.

What will you do?

column439: > The Importance Of Bitcoin and Digital Wallets
column449: class=""dd""><table class=""mob-block"" role=""none"" width=""100%"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" align=""center""><tr><td aling=""center"" valign=""middle""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" align=""right"" class=""socialShare mob-stack""><tr><td align=""left"" valign=""middle""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" align=""left"" style=""width:140px
column477: data-open-tracking=""true""> {{OPEN_TRACKING_PIXEL}}
column478:
>

Looking at money from a zoomed-out perspective most people understand that money can be a form of an accounting system, who owns what, how much do you have and who owns what to who. The future independence for mankind relies solely on the blockchain ledger, no more banks taking 40 cents on your dollar, and no more government telling citizens what they can and can not spend their hard-working money on.
column479: It worries me that more people will look at the risk of losing money in Bitcoin and not taking a chance on the future of finance but will leave with a bank who loans out money they do not even have and in the process committing types of crimes an average citizen would go to jail for. Decentralized Digital wallets in the space would help people stay away from the fees and risk of the centralized money system, the proof — of -work system on the other hand will put the power in the hand of the people being able to be free from the system and helping with privacy payments.
column480: People want to talk about the risk, there have been more than 30,000 data breaches from mom and pop shops to retail stores to banks, privacy is never the main concern for retail stores and banks money is and with more money more problems banks only step up their security to protect what is theirs while they are taking what is ours.
column481: class=""dd"" bgcolor=""transparent""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column485:
border=""0""/>

We have heroes who have been in the space for a long long time trying to get the adoption of Bitcoin noticed and understood, those who do not want to learn or overlook will be left behind to perish, those who do not understand that the blockchain is the future will not succeed. Put this into perspective think of any computer or laptop, Humans are more like the keyboards to the computer, what we call “Nodes” are the computers and “Hashrates” are the fans that make things run.
column486: All we are missing is community even though Bitcoin has been around for some time most of the time has been trying to recruit keyholders to open the doors to adoption with limited people who knew, on the other hand, you still had people thinking their fiat was the best thing in the world shooting down the keyholders so how could we win.
column487: Now fast forward to 2021 where millions have access to unlimited knowledge and multiple ways to buy Bitcoin and acquire a Digital wallet, all we need are people to open their eyes stop betting against the market being over-leveraged on an asset that is here to serve and protect the little guys who are not in control.

column439: > What Makes Amp so Astonishing
column448: > The Future of Asset transferring has arrived!
column449: class=""dd""><table class=""mob-block"" role=""none"" width=""100%"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" align=""center""><tr><td aling=""center"" valign=""middle""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" align=""right"" class=""socialShare mob-stack""><tr><td align=""left"" valign=""middle""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" align=""left"" style=""width:140px
column477: data-open-tracking=""true""> {{OPEN_TRACKING_PIXEL}}
column478: >
column479: class=""dd"" bgcolor=""transparent""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column483:
border=""0""/>

The main force the crypto-asset space has faced over the past decade was that we did not have an asset that provides instant, verifiable assurance for real-world applications. We have never had a protocol in the space to help us transfer our assets so instant and secure until now! Amp, co-developed by Flexa and ConsenSys Amp, is a digital asset built on the Etheruem network, making it an ERC20 token that can collateralize payments, making them instant and secure.

It is also the
column484: native token for the Flexa network
column485: one of the many cool things people can do with Amp is staking through&nbsp
column486: Flexa Capacity. Flexa provides two ways to stake Amp
column487: One can choose Spedn or Gemini for 3.63% APY, connecting one of the famous wallets like MetaMask, Coinbase Wallet, Rainbow Wallet, and Trust wallet. Ensure there is enough Etheruem in the wallet of choice to cover the fees
column488: you will be placed in a liquidity pool from there. Another option is to stake Amp on&nbsp
column491:
this project will change the lives of millions if not billions of people who have to use crypto-asset transfers to survive and provide for their families that could be anywhere in the world.

In some shape or form, we have seen change within how money can go from one place to another. Over the past decade, the prominent asset people had was fiat currency
column492:
the only way most people could send money to relatives was via money order. Now we fast forward, and people can send their fiat currency via Cashapp, Venmo, Apple Pay, and many more options. Flexa is taking us further into the future, giving us the capability to send our more valuable assets like Bitcoin and Litecoin all across the globe. They took the simple stuff from data transactions, flipped it to an asset transaction, and does the same thing that Netflix does data every day. They are helping individuals transact with crypto to provide a payment railing system on the lightning network, sending our assets instantly and safely with low fees day-in and day-out giving more power to the people in a way we did not have before.

If nothing I have said so far has impressed you or made you lift an eyebrow take a look at Amps partnerships and reconsider your negative opinions or thoughts on this project.

These are some of the leaders in the crypto space, and as I mentioned before, this project is still just putting on its tires to gear up for the long race we have ahead in the crypto-world.

column479: >
column480: class=""dd"" bgcolor=""transparent""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column484:
border=""0""/>

For starters, we all know the most potent tool Bitcoin has is marketing. It takes 2 seconds, and the whole world is chatting about how bad it is for the planet or why you should not touch Bitcoin because of how volatile it is.
column485: What about all of the critical factors it has provided over the past four years? Th What makes everything so condescending is that everyone tends to forget that Bitcoin and the Blockchain provided more than 8,000 jobs in 2020. I don't think the government intended to create jobs in 2020, let alone save or economy. They actually ruined it by turning on the money printer and have not turned it off since, but they would not share that information with the world, would they? I did not think so, but yet so far, it seems like the media, politicians, and banks have so much to say about something they barely even understand for most of the year.
column486: The whole world has faced problems with carbon emissions for decades now, and the banks and big businesses in the cities are one of the biggest causes. Banks alone provide more than 30% of funding to projects supporting fossil fuel expansion plans quite odd for an industry striving to keep clean energy. The Government/Federal reserve has so much to say.
column488: class=""dd"" bgcolor=""transparent""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column492:
border=""0""/>

Still, the original monetary system has been volatile all of this time by using money they don't even have, just leaching off of the people paying taxes. No one ever blames the person stirring the pot, just looking to blame the next thing. Meanwhile, Bitcoin has been why the Tech companies can provide jobs
column493:
no one in the media is talking about that or thinking to say that. There 66+ startup companies in New York based on blockchain and regulations having supposed to ban mining? Is it because it is not buying into a market that is drowning

Crypto as a whole has given the people of the world today free will, and most have never experienced it before, so they never understand the actual value of something like Bitcoin. People one day will do their research before believing what they are told
column494:
with everyone having access to Bitcoin and the blockchain ledger, everyone could be their accountant.

Assets of tomorrow, such as cryptocurrency, are just beginning. However, they provide more for the future than the past ever has, once people finally realize that Bitcoin has more to offer than real estate or stocks.

column439: > Economical Feast
column448: > How Crypto-Assets Are Repairing The Out-Dated Economic Infrastructure
column449: class=""dd""><table class=""mob-block"" role=""none"" width=""100%"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" align=""center""><tr><td aling=""center"" valign=""middle""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" align=""right"" class=""socialShare mob-stack""><tr><td align=""left"" valign=""middle""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" align=""left"" style=""width:140px

column479: class=""dd"" bgcolor=""transparent""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column483:
border=""0""/>

The future is not looking so bright in America
column484:
we lack in so many fields when it comes to the economy, and there is no true vision of the future of infrastructure in this country.

This is precisely where Crypto-Assets come into play, considering we immediately started to decline as a country when we cut our ties with gold. Due to greed and those in control, we are disrupting our future of infrastructure just for them to make profits.

Everyone knows these two factors are accurate: those at the top remain at the top because those caught up in their greed give only little to those at the bottom because of their ability to access everything first. The second factor is since the beginning of time, governments tend to always bring their fiat currency to zero.

I wonder what that could be about is the people of the world not paying their taxes? Is it because we spend a lot of money as a country consuming more than what we produce? With everyone pointing the finger at one another, rich pointing fingers at the poor, and the poor point the finger at the rich, no one can see what is going on.

Zoom out and realize the opportunities Blockchain will bring to the table
column485:
not only will our digital infrastructure be more robust. Those who have never had the chance of success turn out of the wholes that their governments put them in for the most part.

There are far more things crypto-asset protocols and Blockchain can do more for humanity than the fiat currency could ever dream of, but why is it being shunned? It is due to the power these people possess. Please take a look at Cardano and the IOHK team
column486:
they made it possible for a place like Ethiopia where only 15% of people who have access to the internet now have a chance to perform within the educational system. Crypto provides while the current fiat system is getting paid to put people in jail.

Meanwhile, in the United States, we have governments going on live debates getting paid to argue
column487: while they are doing that day in and day out, our infrastructure base is crumbling down. Recently the American Society of Civil Engineers rated our country with a D for our current infrastructure. It has been 30 years since the federal government has even thought about doing anything about the infrastructure for today’s world. Where has the taxpayer’s money gone?
column488: class=""dd"" bgcolor=""transparent""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column492:
border=""0""/>

Federal Government spending on water dropped 63% in 1977 to 9% in 2017. Let us not forget the other areas that have taken hit wastewater utilities, inland waters, and of course, our water. This means our current government has no real experience in infrastructure investing
column493:
the proof is in the pudding, watching our economy grow slower and slower.

What if we were to invest in the Blockchain that will not go anywhere for a long, long time. Putting it to use pushes the future forward to grow in size, speed, and strength amongst the communities. Every day ordinary people and wealthy people no longer will have a gap due to power that those at the bottom can not control sometimes. There are no sides, no control, and justice will be served for putting several million people in a suppressed state for decades.

That’s what Blockchain provides, and all the assets that make up the Blockchain also offer for individuals. It won’t guarantee millionaires left and right, but one thing for sure it will not let you have led in your water because you do not live on the rich side of town or because you are some politician who thinks printing close to almost 8 trillion dollars in a year is the answer. The answer is and always has been science.

column439: > Maximize Profits
column448: > How to make passive income with Celsius
column449: class=""dd""><table class=""mob-block"" role=""none"" width=""100%"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" align=""center""><tr><td aling=""center"" valign=""middle""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" align=""right"" class=""socialShare mob-stack""><tr><td align=""left"" valign=""middle""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" align=""left"" style=""width:140px
column477: data-open-tracking=""true""> {{OPEN_TRACKING_PIXEL}}
column478:
>

Create a Celsius account now

What is Celsius Youtube Video

Similar to putting money in a savings account, storing cryptocurrency funds in Celsius earns you interest on your holdings each week. The premise is relatively simple:
column485: >You deposit cryptocurrency into the Celsius app.
column486: >The company then loans those funds out to retail and institutional borrowers.
column487:
>Every Monday, you receive a payment from the revenue that Celsius gains from those loans and other activities. The Celsius team boasts a return of 80% of company revenue to users.

The functionality of the app expands far beyond simple interest payments, though.

On the other side of lending, loans are available through Celsius, as well. By putting up cryptocurrency as collateral, you can take out cash (or stablecoin) loans at a range of different terms. Unlike most traditional loan services, Celsius loans don’t require a credit check and typically grant you an approval in minutes.
column488: class=""dd"" bgcolor=""transparent""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column492:
border=""0""/>

A comparison of interest rates (Source: Celsius)

Although Celsius Network isn’t a wallet, per se, it includes the ability to send and receive supported cryptocurrency through CelPay. CelPay doesn’t charge any transaction fees and enables you to send crypto via a link, message, or directly in-app.
column493:
>

Can you make money with Celsius Network?

Celsius Network gives you the opportunity to earn passive income on your cryptocurrency holdings, but there are a few bits of information of which you should be aware of.

The primary way to earn money with Celsius Network is by receiving interest payments on your holdings. To participate, you simply deposit cryptocurrency into a Celsius wallet. Once you’ve done that, you’ll earn interest payments to your wallet every Monday. You can choose whether you receive these payments in like-kind or in CEL (Celsius’s native token).
column494: class=""dd"" bgcolor=""transparent""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column496: >
column498:
border=""0""/>

Celsius Network offers competitive APRs on several cryptocurrencies.

Beyond traditional crypto interest, Celsius Network also includes the opportunity to earn interest on gold. Rather than actual gold, though, Celsius utilizes XAUt, and ERC-20 token with gold backing.

The annual interest rates vary weekly as well as from coin to coin. However, they seem to generally be in the range of 3.00% to 11.00%. Additionally, choosing to receive your interest payments in CEL will net you a higher return. It should be noted that the “Earn in CEL” is not currently available to U.S. users.
column499: An important warning: Currently, Celsius Network does not provide any insurance on your deposits. So if the company falls victim to a hack, for instance, there is a possibility that you will lose your funds.
column500:
>

Which cryptocurrencies are available on the platform?

Celsius Network pays out interest for a wide variety of cryptocurrencies. The options include (but aren’t limited to):
column512:
>And many stablecoins.

You can also purchase BTC, ETH, XRP, BCH, LTC, and XLM directly in the app.
column513: class=""dd"" bgcolor=""transparent""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column515: >
column517:
border=""0""/>

The Celsius app supports a wide variety of cryptocurrencies.

column439: > What makes a good investment?
column440: class=""dd""><table class=""mob-block"" role=""none"" width=""100%"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" align=""center""><tr><td aling=""center"" valign=""middle""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" align=""right"" class=""socialShare mob-stack""><tr><td align=""left"" valign=""middle""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" align=""left"" style=""width:140px

column473:
border=""0""/>

There are many factors that can contribute to making an investment a good one. Some of the most important ones include:

Potential for financial return: An investment should have the potential to generate a financial return that is commensurate with the level of risk involved.

Alignment with investment goals: An investment should align with an investor's overall financial goals and risk tolerance.

Diversification: Diversification is an important aspect of investing, as it can help to spread risk and reduce the overall volatility of an investment portfolio.

Quality of the investment: It is important to carefully evaluate the quality of an investment, including factors such as the financial strength of the company or fund, the stability of its revenue streams, and the experience and track record of its management team.

Valuation: The price of an investment relative to its underlying value can also be an important consideration. An investment that is reasonably priced relative to its potential returns may be more attractive than one that is overvalued.

Liquidity: The ability to easily buy and sell an investment can be an important factor, especially for investors who may need to access their funds on short notice.

Risk: All investments carry some level of risk, and it is important to carefully consider the level of risk that is acceptable in relation to the potential returns.

column478:
>

Today I’m announcing a brand new addition to my Substack publication: the Changed World by Zoharks subscriber chat.

This is a conversation space in the Substack app that I set up exclusively for my subscribers — kind of like a group chat or live hangout. I’ll post short prompts, thoughts, and updates that come my way, and you can jump into the discussion.

To join our chat, you’ll need to download the Substack app, now available for both iOS and Android. Chats are sent via the app, not email, so turn on push notifications so you don’t miss conversation as it happens.

column483:
border=""0""/>

As tensions rise around the world, many investors are turning to the defense stock sector as a safe haven for their money. But what exactly is driving the increase in demand for these types of stocks, and which companies are worth investing in? We reached out to a panel of experts to get their take on the current state of the defense stock market.

According to military analyst and consultant James R. Smith, the main driver of the increase in demand for defense stocks is the current global political climate. ""With so much uncertainty and potential for conflict around the world, it's no surprise that people are looking to invest in companies that produce goods and services for national defense,"" he says.

But it's not just geopolitical tensions that are driving the demand for defense stocks. Many of these companies are also involved in the production of innovative technologies that have civilian applications, such as drones and cybersecurity software. This makes them attractive to investors who are looking for companies with a diverse range of products and services.

So which companies should investors be keeping an eye on? According to financial advisor and defense industry expert Jennifer Williams, some of the top performers in the sector include Lockheed Martin, Northrop Grumman, and Raytheon. ""These companies have a long track record of delivering strong financial results and are at the forefront of new technology development in the defense sector,"" she says.

Other experts also highlighted the importance of diversification in the defense stock sector. ""It's important to not put all your eggs in one basket,"" says investment strategist David Thompson. ""While the big players like Lockheed Martin and Northrop Grumman are certainly worth considering, there are also a number of smaller companies that are worth looking into. For example, companies like L3Harris Technologies and Textron Inc. are making waves in the sector and could be good investments for those looking for growth opportunities.""

In summary, the defense stock sector is on the rise due to a combination of geopolitical tensions and the development of innovative technologies. While the big players are always worth considering, it's also important to diversify your portfolio and look at some of the smaller companies in the sector. With careful research and a long-term investment strategy, the defense stock sector can be a lucrative opportunity for investors.

Tech stocks have had a long and storied history, with many ups and downs. Despite this, the tech sector has consistently been a major driving force in the global economy and has contributed significantly to our modern way of life.

One of the earliest tech stocks was IBM, founded in 1911. Throughout the 20th century, IBM played a significant role in the development of computing technology and was a pioneer in the field of data storage and processing. Today, IBM is still a significant player in the tech industry, and its stock remains a popular choice among investors.

Another tech giant that has had a long history is Microsoft. Founded in 1975, Microsoft has become one of the world's most well-known and successful tech companies, thanks in large part to the widespread adoption of its Windows operating system. Microsoft's stock has also been a solid choice for investors, with the company consistently posting strong financial results and paying dividends to shareholders.

In recent years, the tech industry has seen the rise of many new companies, such as Google, Apple, and Amazon. These companies have disrupted traditional industries and have become some of the most valuable companies in the world. Their stocks have also been among the most successful in the market, with solid growth and high returns for investors.

Overall, the tech sector has been an excellent place for investors to put their money, with many companies posting strong financial results and delivering impressive returns. As technology continues to advance and shape our world, it is likely that tech stocks will remain a strong choice for investors for years to come.

column483:
border=""0""/>

As the rumors and Noise start flooding the streets, I think it's time we sit back and understand our past to understand where we could take advantage in the present time
column484:
let's talk about the ""Causes and Consequences of the 2008 Recession.""

The 2008 recession, also known as the global financial crisis, was a severe economic downturn that affected countries worldwide. It was triggered by the collapse of the U.S. housing market, fueled by risky lending practices and the widespread use of subprime mortgages that quickly spread to other countries through various financial channels.

The crisis began in 2007 when many homeowners started defaulting on their mortgages. This led to a decline in housing prices, which caused many banks and other financial institutions to suffer substantial losses.

The crisis also led to a decline in global trade and commodity prices. The recession lasted from December 2007 to June 2009, making it the longest and deepest downturn since the Great Depression of the 1930s.

The 2008 recession had a significant impact on the global economy. The stock markets around the world experienced a sharp decline, with many essential indices losing more than 50% of their value. Many businesses were forced to close their doors, particularly in the housing and financial sectors. Unemployment rates also rose significantly, with millions of people losing their jobs.

Governments worldwide took several steps to mitigate the recession's effects. Some measures included increasing government spending, cutting interest rates, and providing financial assistance to struggling businesses and individuals. The Federal Reserve in the U.S. also intervened by introducing quantitative easing, which helped stabilize the financial markets.

column523:
>

Despite these efforts, the recovery from the 2008 recession could have been faster and more balanced. As a result, it took several years for many countries to return to pre-crisis levels of economic growth.

The 2008 recession also had a lasting impact on how we think about the economy and the role of government in addressing economic crises. For example, it led to a renewed focus on regulation and oversight of the financial industry.

The crisis led to a sharp decline in economic activity and a significant increase in unemployment. Many banks and financial institutions failed or required government bailouts, leading to a severe credit crunch that further depressed economic activity. Many countries strengthened their safety nets to support those struggling financially.

In conclusion, the 2008 recession was a significant global event that impacted the economy and people worldwide.

Despite the efforts to mitigate the effects of the crisis, the recovery could have been faster and more balanced. Nevertheless, it has led to a renewed focus on regulation and oversight of the financial industry and support.

This week will be a quiet one on the economic calendar, but several key events are still worth paying attention to. Inflation figures for December in the US will be closely watched,

as they could influence the Federal Reserve's decision on future rate hikes. Additionally, the start of corporate earnings season will provide insight into the health of the economy amid concerns about a potential slowdown.

Other data to keep an eye on include UK GDP, Japanese inflation, and Eurozone industrial production and trade figures. Companies in the S&
column469:
P 500 are expected to report a 1.6% decline in Q4 earnings compared to the same period the previous year, according to Refinitiv IBES.

It is worth noting that this could change if current earnings estimates do not adequately account for any economic slowdown.

border=""0""/>

Dividends are payments made by a company to its shareholders as a distribution of profits. They are usually paid out every quarter but can also be paid annually or semi-annually.

Here's an explanation of how dividends work: A company makes a profit: When a company generates more money than it spends, the excess is considered profit. The company's board of directors decides to pay a dividend: The board of directors, who the shareholders elect, will determine whether or not to pay a portion of the profits as dividends. Dividends are paid to shareholders: Shareholders receive a payment for each share of stock they own.

The board of directors determines the dividend amount, usually expressed as a dollar amount or a percentage of the stock's price. The payment is made on a regular schedule: Dividends are typically paid every quarter but can also be paid annually or semi-annually.

column488:

BOOK OF THE WEEK:
column489:
>

""The Wealth of Nations"" by Adam Smith - This book, published in 1776, is considered the first work of modern economics and is known for its emphasis on the division of labor and the role of markets in the economy.
column493: bgcolor=""transparent"" class=""dd""><table class=""j"" role=""none"" width=""50%"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" align=""center""><tr><td> &nbsp
column494: Dividends can be reinvested or taken as cash: Shareholders can take their dividends as cash or reinvest them in additional shares of stock. Dividend-paying stocks are attractive to investors because they provide a steady income stream and can be an excellent way to generate long-term returns. Note: Not all companies pay dividends, and those that do may change the amount they pay depending on the company's financial situation and strategy.
column500: >Start by creating a budget: Identify your fixed expenses, such as rent or mortgage payments, and your variable costs, such as groceries and entertainment. Then, determine how much money you have left over each month that you can put towards investing.
column501: >Look for ways to increase your income: Consider taking on a side hustle or asking for a raise at work.
column502: >Cut unnecessary expenses: Identify areas where you can cut back, such as subscriptions or memberships you don't use and redirect that money towards investing.
column503: >Invest in yourself: Consider taking classes or obtaining certifications that can increase your earning potential in the long run.
column504: >Start small: Even small amounts of money invested regularly can add up over time.
column505: >Remember that investing in dividends is a long-term strategy, so your approach must be patient and consistent.
column549:
Read Through My Twitter Threads

Dividends can be a powerful tool to help you build wealth over time. Here's a step-by-step explanation of how dividends can make you wealthy: Invest in dividend-paying stocks: When you purchase stocks in companies that pay dividends, you are automatically eligible to receive those dividends as long as you hold the stock.

Reinvest dividends: By reinvesting dividends, you can use the dividends you receive to purchase additional shares of stock, which can increase your overall company ownership. Compound interest: As you reinvest your dividends, you will earn dividends on your dividends, a process known as compound interest. Over time, this can lead to significant growth in your portfolio. Diversify: Diversifying your portfolio by investing in multiple companies across different industries can mitigate risk and increase your chances of earning consistent dividends. Patience: Dividend investing is a long-term strategy that takes time for your portfolio to grow.

You can see significant growth over time by being patient and consistent in your approach. Tax advantage: In some countries, dividends are taxed at a lower rate than other types of income, which can help to increase your overall returns. Regular income: Dividends can provide a steady stream of income, which can be used to supplement your other income sources, such as salary or rental income.

Note: Dividend investing is not a guaranteed way to become wealthy
column550: as with any investment, there is a risk of losing money. It's essential to do your research and consult with a financial advisor before making any investment decisions.

U.S. stocks finished with modest gains on Friday, continuing a positive trend for the second consecutive week in 2023.

The Dow Jones Industrial Average increased by 0.3%, reaching 34,302, while the S&
column475:
P 500 index rose by 0.4%. The Nasdaq Composite Index also saw a gain of 0.7% on Friday, and had an impressive 4.8% gain for the week.

The Dow and S&
column476:
P 500 also saw strong weekly gains of 2% and 2.7% respectively, according to Dow Jones Market Data. The rally in stocks was supported by continued retreat of inflation data, as the December consumer-price index was recorded at a 6.5% annual rate, down from 9.1% last summer.

Book of The Week: Capital in the Twenty-First Century"" by Thomas Piketty - This book, published in 2013, examines the history of inequality and makes the case that increasing wealth concentration is a natural outcome of capitalist economies. https://t.co/8a8UwM8tYp

BUY NOW!

On Friday, investors received updates from major banks JPMorgan Chase and Bank of America as they reported their fourth-quarter earnings.

Additionally, Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen warned lawmakers that the government is expected to reach its borrowing limit next week and urged them to suspend or increase the debt limit.

column439: > Navigating the Risks: Understanding the Differences between Market Risk and Idiosyncratic Risk for Better Investment Decisions
column448: > Market risk vs idiosyncratic risk
column449: class=""dd""><table class=""mob-block"" role=""none"" width=""100%"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" align=""center""><tr><td aling=""center"" valign=""middle""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" align=""right"" class=""socialShare mob-stack""><tr><td align=""left"" valign=""middle""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" align=""left"" style=""width:140px
